awd_titl_txt: Testing the Refugia Hypothesis in Southeast Alaska Using Paleogenetics and Glacial Chronology
awd_abstract_narration:
Vast ice sheets covered northern North America during the last Ice Age. These ice sheets blocked movements of plants and animals between Asia and the Americas for many thousands of years. Many species died out and others were forced into isolated, ice-free areas (refugia) north and south of the ice sheets. Today?s plants and animals carry the genetic legacy of the Ice Age and this refugial isolation, but it is not completely known how it impacted and shaped the past trajectory of many species and their movements following the retreat of the ice sheets. Yet, such knowledge is important for understanding how plants and animals may respond in the future due to environmental changes. The exact extent and timing of ice coverage is also poorly known, and islands along the northwestern coast of North America are hypothesized to have escaped Ice Age glaciation. This means they could have acted as a unique bottleneck for the passage of plants and animals in the geologic past, and even perhaps that they were an early gateway for the peopling of the Americas. This research is aimed at improving knowledge of a critical region for plant, animal, and even human migration: Southeast Alaska. We are testing the hypothesis that coastal areas in Southeast Alaska escaped ice cover by collecting rock samples that will tell us whether or not landscapes were covered by ice and when they became ice-free. We are studying the DNA preserved in fossil bones from mammals that died thousands of years ago. This research project is providing much needed insights into the history of iconic mammals and their environmental conditions in Southeast Alaska.

The westernmost extent and timing of ice cover along the North Pacific Coast during the Last Glacial Maximum is poorly known, leaving unanswered fundamental questions about the impact of climatic change on biotic diversification and postglacial colonization of the Americas. Various lines of evidence point to the existence of a viable, ice-free coastal corridor that may have played an important role for biotic exchange between the Old and New Worlds during the last Ice Age. This project is designed to be the definitive test of the hypothesis in support of coastal refugia. We are taking advantage of cutting-edge technologies in cosmogenic nuclide exposure dating and paleogenetic analyses of an unparalleled fossil collection from caves in SE Alaska to achieve two key objectives: (1) directly determine if SE Alaska provided ice-free refugia for terrestrial mammals during the LGM, and (2) constrain the extent and history of the western Cordilleran Ice Sheet during the LGM. Whether the hypothesis is supported or not, this highly interdisciplinary project will deliver results with high impact and have important implications for many different disciplines spanning the geological, biological, paleontological, and archeological sciences. The results will answer a broad range of key questions about the dynamic glacial conditions of SE Alaska during the Ice Age, biogeographic history of mammal island populations, and the configuration and timing of an available migration corridor for the postglacial peopling of the Americas. This research will (a) provide training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, (b) broadly disseminate results and links to associated relevant topics, such as environmental change and human migration, through a website, and (c) organize a workshop in SE Alaska with public and K-12 outreach components to synthesize past and current research and focus on the intersection between research, natural resource management, and the impact of future climate projections on biotic systems across the archipelago.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the Ice Age (the Last Glacial Maximum or LGM), vast ice sheets covered most of North America and many species died out and others were forced into isolated, ice-free areas, also known as refugia. Although refugia have been recognized south and north of the ice sheets, gaps in knowledge concerning the westernmost extent of the Cordilleran Ice Sheet had left open questions regarding presence of refugia along the Northwest Pacific Coast. For decades, the Alexander Archipelago in Southeast Alaska was thought to be completely covered by ice during the LGM, but multiple lines of evidence supported an emerging hypothesis that areas had escaped ice cover during the LGM. The main goal of this project was to investigate the ice age history of Southeast Alaska and directly test this hypothesis that coastal ice-free refugia existed at locales presently above sea level. To reach this goal, we took advantage of a cross-disciplinary approach applying cutting-edge technologies: (1) cosmogenic nuclide exposure dating of boulders and bedrock samples from previously proposed refugia and elsewhere in SE Alaska to constrain the local ice sheet history, and (2) paleogenetic analyses and radiocarbon dating of mammal remains previously excavated from limestone caves to test if the same populations inhabited this region continuously throughout the LGM, or if populations were extirpated during its peak and later recolonized the region.

The combined results from our cosmogenic exposure dating, radiocarbon dating of subfossil bones, and paleogenetic analyses from a range of mammal species during the life of this award have provided converging lines of evidence consistent with the absence of ice-free LGM refugia along the SE Alaskan coast. We found that a local LGM peak must have been short-lived in a narrow interval around 19-16 thousand years ago (ka), and vegetation quickly expanded once deglaciation began, providing habitats for terrestrial species, and for humans and their dogs to (re)colonize the area. Importantly, however, sea levels during the last glaciation were considerably lower than today’s, exposing parts of the continental shelf, now submerged, that could potentially have provided ice age refugia.

Our cosmogenic exposure dating posed a new ice sheet chronology, in which timing of ice occupation was likely initiated after ~20 ka, and deglaciation started at the southern coast of the archipelago ~16 ka, whereas ice retreated from the northern, outer coastline of Baranof and Kruzof islands at ~15 ka. This new ice sheet chronology was supported by the subfossil record. Although preglacial subfossils have only been recovered from one cave, Shuká Káa, mammal remains were deposited almost throughout the LGM; however, there is a notable hiatus from ~20 to ~17 ka. Immediately surrounding this hiatus are remains of ringed seal, indicating availability of a marine environment to predators of seals (likely foxes). Our paleogenetic analyses of cave bones confirmed the identities of seal and fox specimens. Our results from close to 100 Alaskan brown and American black bear also provided a much more complete timeline of bear residence and history in SE Alaska spanning the last >40,000 years that failed to support a hypothesis of continuous occupancy throughout the LGM for either species, consistent with an absence of refugia. We also identified a dog specimen among cave remains that appeared to be a descendant of dogs that may have accompanied humans ~16 ka, coinciding with the opening of a Northwest Pacific coastal corridor. Finally, genome-scale data from Sitka black-tailed deer supported their glacial survival in a refugium south of the Cordilleran ice sheet, and that an uneven rate of deglaciation along the Northwest Pacific Coast following the LGM may have created temporary post-glacial refugia, providing opportunities for dispersal northward along the coast.     

This project trained graduate and undergraduate students in emerging fields of exposure dating, mammal biology, ancient DNA, and paleogenomics and provided opportunities for at least six graduate students and four undergraduate students. In addition to the biological and geological disciplines, our work also demonstrated value in fields of anthropology and archeology. For example, our discovery of human remains, linking ancient human occupation with present-day Tlingit peoples, has had an impact on the understanding of human history in SE Alaska, a crucial region in the peopling of the Americas. The research team also participated in numerous public outreach activities, communicating science central to this project. We actively collaborated with the Wrangell Cooperative Association (WCA), the federally recognized tribal group associated with the area where the human remains were recovered, on the publication of the paleogenomic results from a ~3,000-year-old female individual, who the WCA named Tatóok yík yées sháawat (‘‘Young lady in cave’’). Cooperation and common goals between Alaska Native tribes and the scientific community, as well as Forest Service archaeologists and Wrangell District rangers, ensured the repatriation of the human remains.
